contextId.information: A throne is a chair that a ruler sits on, and it is a symbol of his authority. If a prince is brought down from his throne, it means he no longer has the authority to reign. AT: "He has taken away the authority of princes" or "He has made rulers stop ruling" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: He has thrown down princes from their thrones

contextId.information: The word "bread" refers to food in general. Food as compared to God, by itself, is not enough to sustain a person. Jesus quotes the scripture to say why he would not turn the stone into bread. AT: "People cannot live on just bread" or "It is not just food that makes a person live" or "God says there are more important things than food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Man does not live on bread alone

contextId.information: The phrase "his mouth" represents him using his mouth. AT: "what he thinks in his heart affects what he says with his mouth" or "what he values in his heart determines what he says with his mouth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks

contextId.information: Bread was an inexpensive food that people ate everyday. It is used here to refer to food in general. AT: "the food we need each day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Bread is often used to represent food in general. AT: "enough cooked food for a meal" or "enough prepared food for a person to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The parts of a woman's body are used to refer to the whole woman. AT: "How good it is for the woman who bore you and nursed you at her breasts" or "How happy the woman who bore you and nursed you at her breasts must be" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]]).
contextId.quote: Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts that nursed you

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. AT: "whispered to another person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

contextId.quote: I will say to my soul

contextId.information: "to eat" or "for a meal." Bread was an important part of a meal and is used in this sentence to refer to a meal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "bread" is used to refer to the whole meal. AT: "he who will eat at the meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"King David's descendant." The word "son" is used here to refer to a descendant. In this case it refers to the one who would reign over God's kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This refers to one of the smallest parts of a person to emphasize that the whole person will not perish. Jesus had already said that some of them would be put to death. So some understand this to mean that they would not be harmed spiritually. AT: "But these things cannot really harm you" or "Even every hair on your head will be safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: But not a hair of your head will perish

contextId.information: The "heart" here refers to the mind and thoughts of the person. AT: "so that you are not occupied with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: so that your hearts are not burdened

contextId.information: "their eyes were kept from recognizing Jesus." The men's ability to recognize Jesus is spoken of as their eyes' ability to recognize him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "something prevented them so they could not recognize him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: their eyes were prevented from recognizing him
